sen.j: 1回目は治承4年（1180年）の平重衡の兵火（南都焼討）によるもので、この時には興福寺が全焼となった。
sen.e: This first occurred in '1180', the fire a casualty in the war [Nanto Yakiuchi (the Incident of Heishi's army setting fire to the temples in Nanto)] of TAIRA no Shigehira, burning down the entire Kofuku-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The first destruction occurred in 1180; the war by TAIRA no Shigehira (Nanto Yakiuchi [the Incident of the Taira clan's army setting fire to the temples in Nanto, Nara]) burnt down the entire Kofuku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 東大寺も伽藍の主要部を焼失する大惨事となった。
sen.e: This fire resulted in a tragic incident, the burning down of major components in the Buddhist temple at Todai-ji Temple.

sen.e: This fire resulted in a tragic incident, the burning down of major buildings of the Todai-ji Temple.

sen.j: この時、大勧進職として東大寺再興に奔走したのは俊乗坊重源（しゅんじょうぼう ちょうげん、1121年 - 1206年）という僧であった。
sen.e: At this occasion, Chogen SHUNJYOBO, in the position of Daikanjin (priest to collect contributions, 1121-1206), made every effort to revive the Todai-ji Temple.
At this occasion, Chogen SHUNJYOBO (1121 - 1206), a priest in the position of Daikanjin (priest to collect contributions) made every effort to revive the Todai-ji Temple.

sen.j: 「勧進」とは仏と縁を結ぶように勧めることで、転じて寺院の再興などのために寄付を集めること。
sen.e: "A kanjin (temple solicitation)" was originally meant to promote a relationship with the Buddha, and a kanjin was to be used as a collecting contribution for the revival of a temple.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Kanjin' (temple solicitation) was originally meant to promote a relationship with the Buddha, and then turned to be to collect contribution for the revival of a temple.

sen.j: またその役を担う僧のことを指した。
sen.e: It would also be represented in the name of the Buddhist priest who honored the position.

sen.j: 重源は当時来日していた宋の鋳工・陳和卿（ちんなけい）らの協力を得て、大仏を再興された。
sen.e: Chogen gained the cooperation of CHIN Nakei, a metal caster who visited Japan from Sung in this period, and others in completing the revival of the Great Buddha.

sen.j: 文治元年（1185年）に開眼法要が営まれた。
sen.e: A Kaigen-hoyo ceremony was held in 1185.

sen.e: At this ceremony, Emperor Goshirakawa took a brush of kaigan to perform the ceremony.

sen.j: また、大仏殿の落慶法要は建久6年（1195年）、後鳥羽天皇、源頼朝、北条政子らの臨席のもと行われた。
sen.e: In addition, in 1195, the rakkei hoyo (a memorial service to celebrate the construction of a temple) of the Daibutsu-den was held in the presence of Emperor Gotoba, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, Masako HOJO.

sen.j: 大仏と大仏殿の2回目の焼失は永禄10年（1567年）、松永久秀の兵火（この時の詳しい戦いの様子は東大寺大仏殿の戦いを参照）によるものであった。
sen.e: The second destruction by fire of the Great Buddha and the Daibutsu-den was the direct result of the war of Hisahide MATSUNAGA (for the details of this war, please refer to "warrior clashes at the Great Buddha Hall of Todai-ji temple").

The second destruction of the Great Buddha and the Daibutsu-den was the direct result of the war by Hisahide MATSUNAGA (for the details of the war, please refer to the battle of the Daibutsu-den of the Todai-ji temple) in 1567.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ。年号補足し表現を変えました。

sen.j: この時は時代背景も違い、復興事業はなかなか進まなかった。
sen.e: The revised enterprise would not progress to the outcome desired, because it was lacking in a similar background and historical period.
Different background and time from the previous reconstruction, it was not pursued as intended this time.

sen.j: 大仏殿はとりあえず仮堂で復興したが、それも慶長15年（1610年）に大風で倒壊した。
sen.e: First of all, the Daibutsu-den was reconstituted with-in a temporary temple, which then collapsed during severe winds in '1610'.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Daibutsu-den was reconstituted with-in a temporary temple, however, was collapsed during severe winds in 1610.

sen.j: 大仏は仏頭が落ち、雨ざらしの無残な首無し状態で数十年が経過した。
sen.e: Meanwhile the condition of the Great Buddha worsened after the head fell. It was subject to exposure of the elements, rain, this horrible visage of the headless Buddha continued for more than ten years.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Great Buddha had its head fallen off and spent several decades in a decrepit headless style with opening to the weather.

sen.j: 貞享元年（1685年）、公慶上人（1648年 - 1705年）は、幕府から大仏再興のための勧進（資金集め）の許可を得、ようやく再興が始まった。
sen.e: In 1685, Kokei shonin (1648-1705) received form the Bakufu a permit of kanjin (soliciting of contribution) for the revival of the Great Buddha, to commence the restoration project.

In 1685, by permitted Kokei Shonin (1648 - 1705) from the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) to collect fund for the revival of the Great Buddha, the reconstruction started at last.

sen.j: こうして元禄4年（1691年）完成。
sen.e: As of '1691', the restoration was completed.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1691, the restoration was completed.

sen.j: 翌年開眼供養された大仏と、宝永6年（1709年）に落慶した大仏殿が現存のものである。
sen.e: During the next year, the Great Buddha was blessed in a consecration ceremony, and then the Daibutsu-den was blessed in a temple construction celebration in 1709; each original structure is present today.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Great Buddha which blessed in a consecration ceremony in the following year and the Daibutsu-den completed in 1709 are exited today.

sen.j: 頭部は江戸時代、体部は大部分が鎌倉時代から室町時代の補修であるが、台座、右の脇腹、両腕から垂れ下がる袖、大腿部などに一部天平時代の部分も残っている。
sen.e: Although the head was repaired in the Edo period and the body was repaired through the Kamakura period to Muromachi periods, several parts of the statue have remained in their original state; dating from the Tenpyo Periods, the pedestal, the side, the sleeves from both arms, and the femur remain intact.

sen.j: 台座の蓮弁（蓮の花弁）に線刻された、華厳経の世界観を表わす画像も、天平時代の造形遺品として貴重である。
sen.e: A line engraved with-in the picture, represented the world view of Kegon-kyo (Avatamsaka Sutra), on the renben (lotus petal) of the pedestal and was an important heritage artifact of Tenpyo Period.

sen.j: 明治時代に建てられた真宗本廟御影堂とともに｢世界最大の木造建築｣としてしばしば紹介される。
sen.e: Today the Goei-do Hall (hall dedicated to the sect's founder) of Shinshu-honbyo Mausoleum, Daibutsu-den is generally introduced as the "The largest architectural wooden structure in the world."

sen.e: [As a side note: in modern construction post the early 20th century there were buildings which exceeded the scale of the Daibutsu-den; this included aviation airship hangers (nine remain today), carried out by U.S. Navy from 1942 to1943, and the Odate Jukai Dome in the Akita prefecture.]
